My hypothesis is that, there is some process of which we are unaware, that comprises a linear transformation of matter from our observable space to another unobservable space, and that, the linear transformation from the unobservable space to our observable space maps most of its measurable characteristics to the null space and only preserves a couple observable characteristics, such as gravity. In other words, just as there are physical/chemical processes that transform the characteristics/qualities of matter, there is some other, currently unknown, process that shifts matter to another set of dimensions that we cannot observe or interact with. However, some characteristics of the other set of dimensions are shared with ours, such as gravity. This means, unless we figure out what that process is, it is essentially impossible for us to ever find dark matter. There isn't a bijection between the space the dark matter inhabits and our own.

As the person in the mine mentioned, there may be an entire standard model of particles that make up the "dark matter" continuum. If so, then could those particles that make up, let's call it Standard Model Prime (SM'), interact with the other particles in SM' like our SM particles, creating an entire universe of galaxies, stars, planets, and possibly even people in the SM' universe? If so, and the calculations and observations say the amount of DM is 5 times that of our SM universe, then perhaps there is a SM' universe and 4 more universes full of particles in their own standard model, SM'', SM''', SM'''', and SM''''', or Standard Model Prime to Standard Model PrimeX5.

One could conclude that our gestalt continuum consists of SIX separate universes, each with their own Standard Model of particles that interact within their universe, but only interact with each other through the distortion of the continuum that we call gravity. Thus, the multiverse theory could explain the existence, and the lack of interaction between the six distinct universes made up of the six sets of Standard Model particles.

Why SIX universes? In a three dimensional continuum that we find ourselves part of, there are SIX directions: X+, X-, Y+, Y-, Z+ and Z-. So each universe corresponds to a different "direction", and universes on different "directions" don't interact except for distortion of the continuum, i.e. gravity.

What is most striking to me about Dark Matter is not the dark matter itself, it's how scientists across the globe need it to exist. Because the alternative is making them very uncomfortable. Because the alternative would mean that both Newton and Einstein got it wrong. Or, well, to be more accurate... that both Newton's and Einstein's theories were incomplete.
But... isn't that the beginning of wisdom, actually? And, resulting from that, the beginning of science? The realization that you do not know something. Socrates said it best, long, long ago... The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing. Which really means that before engaging in any sort of debate or approaching any sort of subject, you have to let go of your own assumptions.
We've been looking for dark matter for decades now and have come up with exactly... nothing. Neither actual evidence of it, nor a description of what it actually is. A comprehensive analysis of it is completely absent. In spite of having looked for decades. Occam's Razor lines up quite well with Socrates here. The hypothesis that makes the least assumptions tends to be the more accurate one.
Either... there is a particle out there that has eluded detection for decades, does not interact with anything, not even itself and therefore, by definition, has to actually remain completely undetectable forever more. Or... we simply do not understand gravity. My money is on humanity not understanding gravity. It's the safer conclusion.
I came to a conclusion decades ago and I think it's important that we start accepting the idea -- What do we not know about reality will always be more than what we do know about it.

There must be another theory that would sound about like this:
Our universe is multidimensional. Matter is also multidimensional. What we're experiencing is mostly limited to a 4D spacetime. Hence models have been conceived to satisfy limited 4D observations.
But if we viewed 4D spacetime as a plane of a 5 (or more) dimensional spacetime, then imagine the 4D objects we interact with - 5D (at least) and the mass that resides over and under the plane - shaping the spacetime around them, hence "altering" the gravity they exert.
So there's not any new, exotic, matter but our good ole' bodies have different gravity "shapes" depending on their 5+D shapes and sizes. Not to mention bodies that don't intersect the plane.
The reason the gravity "anomaly" only manifests at cosmic scale, is probably because bodies are relatively orders of magnitude stretched/elongated in the 5th dimension than in the perceived 4D spacetime.
And particles coming into/out of existence in fact cross through our plane via translation/rotation.

The downside is the (apparent) impossibility to detect or get a sense of what's outside the box, from within the box. But you should take note of the slight morphing of cosmic sized bodies that reveal rotation (and at a lesser degree translation) in the 5+D'th dimension.

Dark matter is light. Sooner or later science will come to the conclusion that photons actually DO have mass, and that the 'dark matter' is actually photons. Perhaps ironically, photons are dark, invisible. You can only see the SOURCE of photons, or things they illuminate. I suspect that one day scientists will agree that when photons are first emitted from stars and other sources, they're pure energy, but over long periods of time they 'condense' into particles that have mass. This way the universe renews from energy to mass. There are a LOT of photons emitted by a galaxy. By the time these photons reach a couple hundred light years from each star, they have condensed to have some mass, and this 'wave' in the mass-profile of the photon-stream becomes extremely massive, exerting a gravitational effect on the outer parts of the galaxy, exactly where we see apparent anomalies in the motion of stars. That photon-wave, being far enough from the galaxy to have had time to form mass, but close enough to exert gravitational influence, forms a kind of invisible envelope of mass around the galaxy. When you see 'gravitational lensing', it's not because photons are tracking around the entirely conceptual 'curved fabric of space time', it's because their mass is attracted to massive objects by the very well-known force of gravity. Light 'bends' around massive objects because it is subject to gravity, because it has mass - it's not complicated. You don't need to invent a criss-crossed rubber-sheet-indented-by-billiard-balls conceptual image of the 'fabric of space-time', that you have to say you believe in to pass high-school physics, to explain bending light. Once scientists can accept light develops mass, a great many questions will be answered. Including how extremely old light is in the red-shift. But that can be for another comment.

14:04 This is an issue plagueing archeology and paleontology as well (and probably a lot of other scientific disciplines). Why wouldn't you be happy if the facts don't match the hypothesis? Because it would disprove your hypothesis. So you're starting the experiment wishing it will give you the result you want, and jubilantly claim victory when you manage to squeeze that result out somehow. This is the wishful thinking fallacy, and it has led to all sorts of proposed "missing links" and what I would like to call "ancient aliens level conclusions" in the past, basing entire systems of hypotheses on what often amounts to a single artifact or bone fragment found in an unexpected place. Only to be conclusively disproven later by more dilligent scientists.

With dark matter, as well as with dark energy, I'm very doubtful we will ever find real undisputable evidence for it. To me both are just signs of misunderstanding the basic mechanisms at work on these scales, a modern equivalent to the miasma that our early modern doctors were sure caused all of our maladies. The only "evidence" we have for it consists of all of the data we have of the universe wildly deviating from what our theory predicted. And instead of concluding that our theory might have some issues, we decided to fill in the massive gap with a substance we can't see or detect, just to make the outcome match the theory. The way I see it, dark matter is like an event where you have a box with some stuff in it, and it weighs fifty pounds in total. You know the box itself weighs say half a pound, and when you reach into the box and pick up the items inside, you know together they weigh about four and a half pounds. But the whole assembly weighs fifty pounds. You try literally everything to make sure it’s not a measuring error, you change scales, modify your formulas, propose new theories, but every time you try that, a contradiction pops up elsewhere. The only conclusion you can come to that doesn’t cause any contradictions is to conclude there are forty five pounds of ‘dark items’, and you begin trying to observe them. You keep looking for other ways to get rid of the need for them but every time it turns into a dead end.

When you see something gravitationally that you did not expect, and you find no particles to explain it, and it occurs in an area of spacetime (low mass) that is unintuitive or unfamiliar  to humans, my best guess is that the shape of spacetime itself is not always what we expect. In relatively high mass regions of spacetime, which is a thing familiar to us humans, living inside of a solar system, within a galaxy, as we do, things are relatively flat and well grounded, with dips corresponding to intense gravitational concentrations (planets, stars, black holes, etc.), with the steepest dips belonging to the most gravitationally intense objects. What about areas of spacetime not nailed down by gravitational objects of sufficient size and quantity? We might assume it would be the same there also, but maybe not. Perhaps spacetime leavens or billows upwards, ever so slightly, in areas of low mass, with larger expanses of low mass spacetime seeing a correspondingly more pronounced effect. What would this positively curved spacetime do? Well, at slighter curvatures, it could cause a gravitationally repulsive effect all along the curve, pushing together things like galaxies, which exist on the edges of such positively curved spacetime, thus accounting for the effects we attribute to dark matter. In deeper voids, such the the spaces between galaxy clusters, the positive curvature could create sufficient repulsive effect, that new spacetime is diffusely created over the intervening parsecs. This would be like a white hole, but extremely diffuse, albeit still very noticeable on the vast scales of the universe. This could account for what we see in dark energy. So there you have it. Both dark energy and dark matter explained by the ever-so-slightly positive curvature of spacetime in regions of low mass, where it billows outwards like a sail, with no points of mass to nail it down. This could also explain the inflation of the early Universe and the trigger for the big bang itself, as not so much an explosion, but a rapid entropic dissipation into newly formed spacetime brought into existence by positive curvature (low mass) outside of the initial concentration of matter-energy.

I think dark matter is grossly over-estimated. One of the main arguments for it was that stars in the outer regions of galaxies are going faster than they would be based on the amount of observable matter in the galaxy and a misapplication of Kepler’s Third Law, but when you consider the forces applied by other galaxies located outside the galactic plane and especially nearby galaxies in the axial direction and by matter ejected from supermassive black holes, you should expect the outer stars to not follow a solar system-like speed-vs-distance from the centre curve. And another factor that has the same effect of speeding-up the outer stars is that they get a tow from passing inner-stars, which are far more numerous and far closer proportionally than planets in the solar system.

And much of the actual dark matter is probably just neutrinos, photons, black holes, brown dwarfs, dust and other ordinary matter that doesn't glow brightly enough to be seen.

It won't prove the existence of dark matter even if they do find synchronised variations in the northern & southern hemispheres, because the false positives may well depend on the Earth's speed through the galaxy. False positives correlated with our speed relative to the galaxy may come from cosmic rays or the CMB.

I’ve always thought that dark energy and dark matter actually don’t exist. Let me explain—as for dark energy, it’s always been way more plausible to me that we just don’t have the proper measurements and calculations of gravity and how gravity operates on very large scales within structures such as filaments that contain enormous clusters of galaxies interacting with enormous clusters of galaxies. That’s just one example. My point being that galaxies moving away from each other at faster speeds could potentially be explained by gravity operating on scales so large that it’s difficult for humans to understand, measure, and process.
I’ve also felt the same way about dark matter— I understand that currently it’s a major explaining force on why galaxies don’t fly apart at their current spin rates (as an example), however I think that humans just don’t fully understand properties and gravities of supermassive black holes. Instead of inventing a matter, I believe it’s far more plausible that supermassive black holes are responsible for why galaxies don’t fly apart and conducting much more intensive studies of supermassive black holes may help us better understand the phenomena.

Clearly I am no physicist, nor do I study astronomy or cosmology. I’m an amateur on these topics although I soak up as much material as I can. I just think it can be difficult once a theory becomes so popular for people in these fields to think in different ways and outside the box. I know I’m not the only one to think this way and there’s actually been growing support for these ideas even in professional fields, I would love to see how the debate goes in the coming decades.

I subscribe to the theory that the entire universe we inhabit is confined to the surface of a hypersphere.

Imagine a 3-dimensional sphere, and there is a 2-dimensional being confined to the surface of the sphere. They can curve through 3-dimensional space by traveling along the sphere's surface, but they would still be limited to two axes of movement in their frame of reference. Up-down, and left-right. They would not be able to bury into or lift themselves off of the surface of the sphere, nor would they be able to observe anything that exists external to the sphere's surface.

If we 3-dimensional beings held a magnet above the surface of the sphere, anything magnetic within the 2-dimensional being's universe would still react to it, but the being would not be able to see the magnet. Likewise, if a massive object passed close enough to the 2-dimensional being's sphere, they would observe the effects of gravity without being able to observe the source of that gravity.

Perhaps dark matter is just regular matter floating around out there, still interacting with our universe via gravity, but we simply can't observe it because it exists somewhere along the 4th spacial axis, which we can't observe or traverse.

I've had this crazy pet "theory" for dark matter for a decade now. You know, the kind someone on an "audience" level fan of physics like me would have.

- Gravity has an effect across parallel universes. Dark matter is the gravity effect from other universes.
- The more "unattached"/different/distant a parallel reality is, the less it contributes as dark matter gravity in ours.
- If you add up all parallel universes, a very small number of which will be close and the vast majority will contribute minuscule amounts, you end up with about 5 times the dark matter effect from other universes as the matter in your own.
- The effects of dark matter vs regular matter distribution can be explained via phase differences in the universes, maybe interference effects.

Color me skeptical on dark matter.

1. If dark matter only interacts gravitationally, that means it interacts gravitationally with itself too, no? If so then it would collapse into its equivalent of black holes and stars. Since there's so much more of it, it would make black holes at a much faster rate than regular matter. In fact, regular matter would pool into the spacetime holes made by dark matter like water into a puddle.

2. All spherical celestial bodies (black holes, neutron stars, stars, planets, moons) would lie at the center of a dark matter blob since that is where the regular matter is being pooled. Meaning that our own planet is experiencing the gravity of dark matter right now. So the strength of gravity from regular matter would be a lot less than we think it is and would need to be subtracted from the dark matter blob.

3. But that just puts us back to square one, since the original estimates for distant galaxies were made by what we thought the gravitational strength of regular matter was. We just went in a circle.

I think the more likely possibility is that there is a mistake in what we are perceiving and measuring. The cosmic distance ladder is built on a set of assumptions, which if undermined sends the whole thing back to the drawing board. It could be that these stars in distant galaxies aren't moving at the speeds and distances we think they are.

There is no such thing as dark matter.  The weirdness we see is that there is a very slight difference in speed between light and gravitational waves.  In the deep emptiness of outer galaxies (where ' dark matter' is), this speed difference causes gravitational waves to lap photons, and over large distances, this lapping appears to be extra gravity when in fact it is just gravitational waves affecting photons multiple times.  We think of it as a surfer riding on a wave, but the reality is the surfer is being hit by multiple waves when the ocean is big enough and empty enough.. Dear science/space people, I have a question...

antimatter...
could anti-matter repel regular matter?
what I mean is, could it be possible that gravity has a polarity like positive and negative?


as a hypothetical example, regular matter attracts matter via gravity. perhaps, antimatter attracts antimatter in the same way, but anti matter and regular matter repel each other. Of course matter and anti matter annihilate upon contact, so this would need to be on a galactic scale, or even clusters of galaxies... the point being, this interaction of different matter types would really never be seen in nature since not only do they annihilate, but they also repel.

a way to visualize this would be the standard stretched cloth experiment, except instead, the anti-matter in the system would be represented by a ball with vastly increased buoyancy (it floats upwards) which is placed under the sheet. of course in a normal stretched cloth experiment the gravity "well" is formed by placing a large mass in the middle of the sheet, thus repelling this "antimatter"

this would for the most part, behave exactly as normal, however in areas where antimatter exists, the sheet would be deformed inversely pushing up on the cloth, creating a kind of 'negative' gravity, repelling the regular matter (or at least trying to, the visualization is imperfect in many ways) this "antimatter" would eventually roll "upwards" towards the outside of the sheet.

HOWEVER in an antimatter based gravity well (which in the cloth experiment, could be represented by sticking a pole under the sheet causing a spike pointing upwards. this would allow antimatter to work just like regular matter would in the original version, only "upside down", instead with objects interacting with the cloth on the underside. they would be attracted to the gravity of an antimatter gravitational system...

If you take a size of a galaxy and fill it in with colloidal matter, now you have a very large mass,
which is spread around equally for most of such matter.
Only the slightest introduction of a slightly larger mass in any single spot will draw in
more matter towards it, creating a microgravity, which then draws in more matter,
which after billions of years then results into what we see today, stars and planets.
This however does not negate the fact that colloidal matter is still out there in the same density
as the rest of the visible galaxy, but moving little with speeds nearing zero.
So, basically the galaxy as we know and see it and all that mass is also existent outside of it,
but it has not shaped into anything yet, since the movement is near zero.
This then explains the large mass we can't see and yet exists.

Even within the galaxy there's space where this colloidal matter is maintained, invisible
yet most persistent and adding gravity to the whole of the galaxy.

In fact, you can calculate the universal matter constant from this.
Only in places where there was a minor matter constant imbalance did visible stars and galaxies start to form.
the rest of the universe which appears empty still has the same amount of matter in it per cubic meter,
when compared to what we can actually see.
When you go back in time far enough, and calculate the maximum speed matter can have in
order to not have created stars and/or galaxies you can then also see how far things have to be
from any gravity source in order to meet the requirement of not having accelerated towards
a single spot in order to create something the size of a star from all the local colloidal matter.

For a single calculation, at 81 thousand light years, the sum of acceleration over 1.000.000.000 years is yet
only 7 m/s for the gravity exerted by the Sun. And this also happens with galaxies, which may have
tremendous gravity exerted by the sum of it's components, and yet after a mere million light years,
matter wil only move towards it with even less speed, even after 15.000.000.000.000 years.
Yes, there's expansion, and yes there's slowing down, and yet there's no dark matter or dark energy.

Great video! Just one grating error that I caught and didn't see anyone else catch at 1:42. The pie chart with the dark matter and ordinary matter shows "5x" beneath it and you say that there's 5x more dark matter than ordinary matter when you showed the chart. However your chart actually shows a smaller ratio of dark matter to ordinary matter. Because of the particular ratio and the fact that you've represented it as a pie chart it's actually pretty obvious the ratio is wrong if you know what to look for in the visual (I won't get into the details now but there are some easy techniques you can use to see that it's not right without having to measure anything). The angle on the slice representing Ordinary Matter should be 60°, meaning the pie chart could be broken up into 6 equal-sized pieces where 5 of them are Dark Matter and 1 is Ordinary Matter giving a 5:1 ratio Dark to Ordinary Matter. I measured the angle in GeoGebra and found it to be 72°, meaning your pie chart shows a 4x ratio instead of a 5x ratio.

Pie charts are designed to show parts of a whole. This is either the result of a simple mistake (forgetting that your pie chart should represent a whole equal to 6 identical pieces to make a 5:1 ratio) or it's a misuse of a pie chart. The total area of the circle is 5x the size of the piece of Ordinary Matter and if the slice of Ordinary Matter had been shown side-by-side with the circle representing all Dark Matter it would be fair because there would be no mistaking the visual ratio. But a pie chart, by design, represents the total of all of its parts and so you are presenting a visual with a 4:1 ratio (with 5 equal sized slices, one representing Ordinary Matter and four representing Dark Matter).

In all fairness the auditory and visual clues saying 5x should be enough to have avoided misinforming viewers of the ratio, but the visual's impact was diminished by the misrepresentation of the ratio which is unfortunate.

I like to imagine that all the "light matter" particles are special solutions of some equation that respect some type of symmetry, and that dark matter is just every other solution that doesn't possess that symmetry. That would be great because it would neatly tie up the whole standard-model-seems-arbitrary problem. It would also fit well in the framework of force-carrying gauge bosons. In other words, particles of all masses (up to the Planck mass, I guess) exist, but only the ones that follow the same symmetries as the matter that we are made of can be detected because we detect them through those symmetries. It's a form of selection bias, but on better footing than the anthropic principle because gauge symmetries are well understood to underlie the interactions between light matter particles.

Dark Matter may exist, but you avoided most of its controversy.
The problem with DM is the same as String Theory: it is based more on hypotheses than evidence.
While human intuition has an important role in physics, you have to have experimental data early to avoid boondogles.
All of the evidence for DM is more parsimoniously explained by several other hypotheses (the floor limit, that your guest explained, but also other gravitational effects, including the slowing of light as it travels vast distances because of gravity). It also has equal parsimony (which is to say weak) with other concepts like an extra dimensional superstructure to the universe that actually causes gravity, and differences in regional gravity are due to the geometry of the superstructure (an analogy would be a splash of water on a "2d" surface, when that plane is actually wrapped around a 3D sphere. To the 2D inhabitants, the splash would appear from no where. Assuming a splash on the top of the ball, the water would accelerate more quickly as it approached the equator, given the slope of a sphere).

...again, DM may be the actual explanation, but avoiding the controversy is the same pop-sci sin that has led to decades of wasted talent in String Theory. Experimentation must be allowed to falsify, or point to a more parsimonious explanation. Neither DM nor ST have followed the scientific method in this regard, and that has been fueled, in no small part, by pop science communicators.

The concept of Dark Matter has been essentially the concept of positive and negative.
If matter is the positive, there must be a negative.
...but matter is not strictly positive. It is both positive and negative, removing the need for dark matter to exist. But if one MUST think in such terms, one could effectively consider space itself, or time, or gravity to be dark matter. OR mathematically it would also work out if one considers the dark matter to be another dimension, unobservable because it isn't within our universe, but capable of equally effecting, and being effected by our universe.
In short, Dark Matter is like scientific philosophy. A doctrine through which one can look at the universe. It is no more or less factual than any other perspective, but it is just that. A way of thinking about the universe. Not a static reality of the universe. There are several such philosophies within science, especially today's gatekept fields acting as more religious cults interpreting evidences to fit narrative stories rather than acting as neutral observers and seekers of truth.
Is that bad? Not necessarily. One can think of cold as moving, and thus as a form of energy, even though what would be observed and described would be nothing more than an inverted view of how heat energy works. Wouldn't be wrong. It would just be a focus on the negative rather than the positive function of the same energy.
So if it's easier for you to understand the universe in thinking of invisible dark matter all about us, then it serves the purpose to promote study and increase your knowledge. Like so many thought tools; Schrodinger's cat, Occum's razor, two dimensional objects = all literal fictions that have real world applications and are useful ways of looking at things so long as the observer does not lose sight of the reality that our way of looking at the evidence, is merely one way among infinite ways of observing and analyzing the universe.

When measuring the galactic rotation, is the gravity to be assumed to be a constant pull towards the centre, or are the gravity of the stars spread out though the center to rim taken into account? The majority of the gravity in a galaxy does not come from the super massive black hole at the center. There is a significant amount of stars in the galactic rim that would cause other stars to be pulled towards them. The ridiculous massiveness of galaxies mean that we cannot assume that it is a singular gravitational object to those inside of the galaxy. As the stars travel they would also be pulling the stars behind them in a gravitational slingshot. An example star can be making it's way towards the galactic rim. On average, as the star moves it would attract other local stars it passes and give them a gravitational boost towards the rim while those stars would alter the example star path to curve back towards the centre as well as the majority of the galaxy gravity being located on a single side.

To me it would seem like a self perpetuating cycle of stars being attracted to the opposite side of the galaxy rather than the centre, and as it moves it's own gravity will interact with local stars to give them a boost towards the edge. Those on the edge should be moving the fastest because they have more velocity than any of the other stars with an entire galaxys worth of gravity pulling them towards the center. This would result in the edge having on average stars with higher velocities than those who populate in the arms and center.

Dark matter is the corrective math that we use to true up our limited mathematics with our observations. We had to invent something that is 85% of the universe to make our math work.

We did the same thing with mercury's precession. We used our limited math to conjure up an entire planet that HAD TO EXIST between mercury and the sun whose gravity was causing mercury's unaccounted for precession.

Of course, the reality of the situation was that we lacked an understanding of what was taking place.

That same condition prevails when vieing galaxies at a distance.

We assume that they (the distant galaxy) is suspended on a minkoski type space. And we then take 'orbital' velocities of stars at different distances from the center to determine masses etc.

But what we arent recognizing is that the entire galactic system is in rotation with some very pronouncced time dilation taking place near the center.

How do you tease out rotational velocity from orbital velocity?

The most exciting thing to me about this is how eerily similar this is to how physicists were pursuing Aether Theory right up until Einstein proposed his Theories of Relativity.

They were suspicious that an invisible aether flowed through the cosmos and that it was the medium that conducted light. They devised identical simultaneous experiments all over the globe to try to detect the subtle changes in the flow of aether based on whether one part of the Earth was rotating into it while the other part rotated out of it.

While they were doing this, Einstein was quietly playing with the formulas and discovered that holding the speed of light constant and allowing everything else to vary produced accurate and predictable results. Maybe the next Einstein is doing the same to Dark Matter right now.

Sorry - but you are very wrong when you say that "according to most theories Dark Matter only interacts through gravity". Gravity is the only known interaction of Dark Matter but the vast majority of theories of DM have it interacting through other known interactions such as the W, Z or Higgs bosons or via other more exotic mechanisms such as mixing or new interactions. The reason for this is that if DM only interacts through gravity then no experiment for the foreseeable future will be sensitive enough to detect it.

The great physicist Dr R. P. Feynman has given a
wonderful description of what is “understanding the
nature”. Suppose we do not know the rules of chess
but are allowed to watch the moves of the players. If
we watch the game for a long time, we may make out
some of the rules. With the knowledge of these rules
we may try to understand why a player played a
particular move. However, this may be a very difficult
task. Even if we know all the rules of chess, it is not
so simple to understand all the complications of a game
in a given situation and predict the correct move.
Knowing the basic rules is, however, the minimum
requirement if any progress is to be made.
One may guess at a wrong rule by partially
watching the game. The experienced player may make
use of a rule for the first time and the observer of the
game may get surprised. Because of the new move
some of the rules guessed at may prove to be wrong
and the observer will frame new rules.

We think of space and matter as two totally separate things. However in the beginning all matter arose from space. As matter was forming it is helpful to think that it just didn't form randomly with no precursor but rather formed where there was a 'forming agent' such as a slight dip in the energy of space at that point. So it formed in a mini gravity well that was inherent in space in the very early stages of the Universe. As the Universe began to age these mini gravity wells containing fundamental particles combined into larger gravity wells containing more fundamental particles. To an entity like us who see using visible light it would appear that the particles are creating gravity, whereas what I'm saying is that space energy wells is the source of gravity. Taking this a lot further it would seem reasonable to expect a lot more space energy wells or mini gravity wells that would outnumber particles by some factor. This would look like dark matter. To summarise this would mean that gravity wells would combine into larger and larger gravity wells of space, some containing matter and some not. This would lead to the formation of galaxies we see today. In other words it is not matter that was the cause of galaxies but the combining of space gravity wells that took matter with them and the excess of space gravity wells containing no matter over space gravity wells containing matter would represent dark matter.

Let's assume that Dark Matter exists and it interacts with the regular matter through the gravitational field. I assume that wherever we see a regular matter, the dark matter should be there too due to gravitational attraction. Every star should contain some amount of Dark Matter in its core. The ratio between regular matter and dark matter should not be identical between stars, because nothing in the universe is perfectly homogeneous. Therefore, there should be many stars that look identical from a regular matter point of view, but contain different amounts of dark matter. I assume that if it was the case, we could detect the discrepancies between stars that have the same mass and composition of regular matter, but different total mass contributed by Dark Matter. Such discrepancies do not exist, isn't it a strong indication that Dark Matter does not exist?

interesting paper, it incorporates features of general relativity before Einstein:
Representations and Implications of Papers Written by E.T. Whittaker in 1903 and 1904

In light of the fact that gravitational theories today face certain theoretical
difficulties – the requirement for dark energy, the requirement for dark matter,
the existence of unphysical gravitational singularities, and incompatibility with
Quantum Mechanics – it may be useful to uncover and explore older classical
theories of gravity that overtly or implicitly offered several features of General
Relativity. One such theory was put forward by E.T. Whittaker in 1903 and
1904. His 1903 paper on partial differential equations anticipated General Rel-
ativity in many ways by positing both an undulatory theory of gravity and a
gravitational static field that resulted from effects propagating through the field.
His 1904 paper on two scalar potential functions constructed the electromag-
netic wave from two scalar potential functions, showing that the electromagnetic
four-potential of General Relativity may possess a degree of arbitrariness. This
paper will serve to review these two overlooked papers and highlight some of
their overt and implicit implications.

I think the problem of not finding “dark matter” or any corresponding “particles” is a fundamental one. Let me explain.

Imagine our universe lies on a brane. And for visualization purposes, this brane is like a “sheet”. If I stuck lumpy objects, made of ordinary matter, under the sheet, the effect would be like gravity. We use the same “rubber sheet” model for gravity, except now this is on a much larger meta scale.

You’ll never “detect” discrete particles or anything, because it’s under the sheet. Ironically, and probably more scary, is that if matter/energy did poke a hole in the sheet, it would be monumentally cataclysmic; a “big bang” dare I say.

Anyways, the way I think of my sheet model, if you were going to detect anything if the “sheet” is permeable at all, it would probably be “easier” to do so near a super massive black hole. Where the “sheet” is likely the “thinnest” or closer to the dark matter “outside” of the universe. But even then it still may be impossible. It may be that the macro effect (“gravity”) is the only clue we are going to get. That it exist. If the brane isn’t permeable enough, you’ll never know anyway.

Staunton City Council Unanimously Passed Resolution Condemning Forced Organ Harvesting
The city council of Staunton unanimously passed a similar resolution on October 14, 2021, two weeks ahead of schedule. Mayor Andrea Oakes thanked local Falun Gong practitioners in her speech for educating the community about the issue. She said she had communicated with Virginia State Delegate John Avoli about the resolution. Mr. Avoli expressed his support for the resolution, as well as Vice Mayor Mark Robinson.

During the council meeting, the sponsor of the resolution, Councilwoman Carolyn Dull, spoke about how local residents should pay attention to forced organ harvesting in China and avoid unknowingly participating in this type of organ transplants. i'll never forget when i really learned the effect of dark matter. i was doing some newtonian physics problems, and one of them was to determine the rotational rate of the solar system relative to the milky way galaxy. if you use newtonian math, you get a wildly different number compared to the actual observed period. the answer in the physics book also had the newtonian value as the "correct" answer. the book was wrong probably because the chapter was on newtonian physics, and more specifically rotation, and it was easier to just print the answer you get from taking that approach. i compared my work to the observed value though, and it drove me insane until my professor explained that the answer is MUCH faster because of dark matter. we are hauling ass compared to what we should expect

There are two main ways to explain these anomalies (apart from MOND): dark matter or non-linearity.


* DARK MATTER increases the gravitational differential between a galaxy interior and deep intergalactic space by boosting the strength of gravity where matter is present (by invoking the idea of some form of invisible extra matter that "shadows" normal matter, and increases a massed region's mass).
* NONLINEARITY creates the same increased gravitational differential by by instead reducing the gravitational flux-density in deep space, to below what we would normally calculate as being the average background “floor”.


The justification for nonlinearity is that the universe’s expansion can be taken as an indicator of cosmological time. Time should run slightly faster in intergalactic space, so expansion should happen faster there, which in turn should further increase the rate of timeflow. It’s a positive feedback effect, and it explains the huge bubble-like voids that show up in deep-space surveys, with galaxies concentrated as walls and strands between adjacent pairs and clusters of voids. Under this explanation, these structures happen not because galaxies have some freaky property that causes them to form walls and strands, but because the faster-expanding bubbles leave galaxies behind, concentrated in the denser geometrical features that form between the expanding voids.


Nonlinearity makes the inertial properties of a galaxy's masses behave in a more self-contained manner, with external references having a reduced effect. The outer edges of a rotating galaxy then don’t feel themselves to be rotating as quickly as we reason they must be with respect to outside systems, and there’s a reduced centrifugal effect trying to fling that matter outwards. We then also expect increased lensing effects for galaxies, with an increased field-differential caused not by the gravitational flux-density being increased inside the lensing objects, but being decreased outside.



The advantage of invoking nonlinearity is that it explains what we see, from first principles, without having to invent new invisible entities that have different rules.
The advantage of invoking dark matter is that hypothesising something "new" to explain the gap between what current theory predicts and what we actually measure is often psychologically easier than saying, "Hey, maybe the evidence is simply telling us that our current theory is wrong and needs some changes!".

In theory, theoretical physicists love to be proved wrong.
In practice, some of them are too culturally and emotionally committed to whatever version of physics theory was dominant when they took their degrees to be able to even consider the idea that what they were taught might not be entirely correct.

d. When we look at solar systems between ours and the center of the galaxy, those solar systems would be getting pulled faster towards the center than ours, hence also seeing a red shift of energy.

I like that you made a video about dark matter but I do think you have chosen a weird angle. There are tons of dark matter experiments out there that are much more sensitive and well under control than DAMA-Libra. If the signal is really a dark matter one, models have to be insanity tuned so that the non-detection in other experiments can be explained. Meanwhile, DAMA-Libra just continued measuring for almost 20 years without meaningful changes in equipment or experimental setup. One of the most obvious causes, as you point out.
Similarly, you start the discussion about dark matter with the idea of modified gravity. Sure it works for the rotation curves, but there is a reason the dark matter particle model is popular.
Feels to me like it is just interesting to zoom in to the 'one genius or experiment who gets it' which is a nice narrative, but not always how it works in real science.

But when you come up with an implausible value in a measurement, the simplest explanation is not that 85% of everything is magical stuff you can't see, touch, or interact with. The easiest explanation is that you measured wrong. If you can't figure out why it's wrong, it still seems more likely that it's a fundamental misunderstanding of a law of physics causing the anomalous answer.

There are so many things we don't know, and things we don't know that we don't know, that it seems just as likely that we don't yet understand enough to even know the right question to ask to solve this. The happy coincidence of this is that the correct answer actually could be 85% of everything being something we don't know how to find and that I am completely wrong.

I don't know nearly enough about these subjects to take any sort of a hard stance and I know that because of my lack of in depth knowledge, I am probably wrong. Still, for now I have to say I'm skeptical that everything we have done in the past is 100% correct and the only possible answer is something so extreme. I feel like there should be a simpler solution than what for now feels like magical thinking.

Beautiful and interesting! Thank you! :)
Nevertheless, some terminology is a tad off... ;)
What you call "evidence" of Dark Matter, it is in truth evidence that there is New Physics to be discovered; that there are phenomena we currently can't describe / understand correctly with the theories we have. Dark Matter is entirely hypothetical, and its existence is mere speculation: we even have no idea what it might be, and, truth be told, we have never found any direct evidence of its existence, so far. There are other promising ways to explain the phenomena you mentioned in the video, WITHOUT resorting to some unfathomable "dark" matter: a 5th Force we aren't yet aware of; a better, more comprehensive Theory of Gravity (which should be reconciled with Quantum Mechanics, for instance); and many other possible explanations.
In simple words, phenomena that we can't explain (yet) with the Physics we have, are NOT "evidence of Dark Matter"! :) Peace! :)

If the early universe was much smaller and denser, there would have been many large stars that went super nova. If only 60% of the mass goes on to reform the next generation of stars then 40% of each generation becomes cold dark ordinary matter. After three or four generations of star formation only about 15% of the original mass of the universe would still be luminous. The rest is cold, dark ordinary matter which would be invisible to our telescopes but could be detected by the gravity it exerts. There's precedent for hard to reproduce experiments, but consistent results over decades producing new physics. Ray Davis had a vat of cleaning fluid in a South Dakota mine that detected neutrinos when a Chlorine atom in his cleaning fluid interacted with a neutrino and transformed it into an Argon atom. His results continually showed 1/3 of Argon you'd expect. The numbers were VERY small (something like 10s of atoms in a few weeks), but they were consistent for decades. He wasn't taken too seriously because many assumed the Argon atoms just got trapped somewhere. He started around 1970, and It took until 1987 until an experiment in Japan reproduced his results, though even this experiment showed 1/2 what you'd expect, not 1/3.

Through more experiments all over the world, we now know Ray's experiments were consistently right all along. We now know this as Neutrino osculation. Ray got the Nobel for his work in 2002.

The other, much harder possibility is that dark matter never interacts via anything but gravitation, and all the particle detection efforts are doomed to failure.

This might come off like a silly question because my background knowledge in this is quite limited. But is there any possibility the effects of dark matter is an emergent property of phenomena we already understand at their basic level ? For example is it possible at these really large scales, the forces and fields we are already aware of can behave in ways we never anticipated ?

For example before the theory of evolution was introduced it almost seemed ridiculous that such complex organisms so finely tuned could just appear by chance. The idea a simple watch had a designer, but not an animal that's many times more complicated didn't, was given as proof of an "ultimate designer".

However it turned out the need for an outside designer (in this case dark matter) was completely unnecessary when what was really required was a better interpretation of how a species of animals changes over long stretches of time. The fact we also have dark energy to explain an expanding universe makes me suspect this may be the flipside of the same coin.

Fascinating and educational as always. It's true that Lambda-CDM has some elegant properties explaining large gravitational phenomena, but it has some holes as well, which point towards modified gravity. Dr. Lewis alluded to the "floor" or lowest acceleration due to gravity. This isn't a theoretical construct, but an observation about galaxy rotation curves. The transition from "newtonian" (inverse square law) to "flat" rotation velocities always happens at exactly the same gravitational acceleration. Nothing about the dark matter hypothesis explains or predicts this result. Erik Verlinde's "emergent" or "entropic gravity" theory does explain this phenomena (entropy density in de-sitter and anti-de-Sitter spaces) and fits well with the other difficult tests presented (lensing, cluster behavior). I would love to see you dive further into the theoretical side of this debate.

For anyone interested in the ignorant opinion of an uninformed ignorant.

There is no "Dark Matter", like there is no "Gravity".
Gravity is a RESULT of the existence of particles, and Dark Matter is a version of gravity.
Particles are not... particles: they are waves.
The more power they have in, the more gravity they generate around them (atomic weight, to give an example) by distortion of space.
They essentially DIG a hole into Ether.

Now, what we experiment HERE, inside the Solar System and inside the Milky Way, is the LOCAL part of gravity.
With this I mean that in a place with high density of matter, gravity in good part (about 85%) NULLIFIES itself, due to reverb occurring in opposite direction, by the gravitational waves emitted by all the matter around.

Gravity happens at different SCALES, exactly because of how the waves interact.
We are not only attracted to bodies, but also compressed by gravity itself.
This is why locally we only see about 15% of gravity.

So what is Dark Matter?
Once you leave a location with high density of matter, what remains is waves all going the same direction: outwards the galaxy.
Gravitational waves are emitted by the galaxy, and there's no other material body around to interfere with that, so we see the remaining power of gravity.
This is why we see 85% of gravity more outside galaxies than locally.

We should read gravity like a pool with raindrops, with a huge number of raindrops that represent the particles.
Each drop will emit waves when hitting the surface, and INSIDE the pool, there will be a "pressure" generated by those waves.
But if there is a bunch of drops in a location, you will see more waves coming from that group.
And if you are just doing an experiment, dropping drops in the middle of a swimming pool, you will see that in that location there will be a "quantum sea" where all the waves cross each other, except where they are more concentrated.
And at the same time you will see that coming out of the area of the experiment, all the waves are more or less concentric: there is no interposition by other waves coming from other sides: there you have your 85% of gravity, your Dark Matter.

We may be just getting a hint about this with the last data coming from the Voyager 1, that look completely odd: the Voyager has left the Solar System, and thus gravity has changed where it is now. This is why data is screwed up.
Leaving the Galaxy would mean an even weirder reading.

Dark matter is probably just another aether... a placeholder theory for something not yet understood... imo. There's a simple concept that's been overlooked, I call it electromagnetic star migration. It is based on the idea that a big factor in a star's migration is its own emissions within its environment. If its emissions back up (producing a sort of pressure) in one direction, then it will migrate in the other direction where its emissions more freely escape. This could also partially explain how different galaxies form, which could be based on an area of space where stars either emit more or less freely. From our limited perspective in time and space, and our inability to detect these kinds of directional pressure from emissions, it would be impossible to detect.

But there was a more recent scientific event that gives some credence to the theory. It was the faux headlines saying "a parallel universe was detected" by ANITA when radio waves were found moving in the opposite direction of Earth's magnetic field. A more obvious explanation, to me, was that the rate at which the particle waves were flowing caused a traffic jam and forced some backward without changing the particles' polarization. This would show at least that the rate of flow can create a sort of force.

Regarding the gravitation lensing observed in the absence of matter (considered to be proof of dark matter), I also think would be explained by the ability of electromagnetism to produce a lensing effect. It's known this can occur, but the question not explored is if an enormous amount of these microscopic lensing effects from unseeable tiny charged particles across a vast distance could produce the massive lensing we're seeing.

The eternal hunt for dark matter is what happens when one's observations don't support their theory but they're too arrogant or stupid to look for an alternate theory. It's exactly like the epicycles that geo-centrists invented to try and salvage their theory. Maybe if you add enough epicycles, you can explain the movement of the planets without having to admit that they aren't revolving around the earth.

Likewise, if you add enough imaginary matter, you won't have to question the notion that gravity is the fundamental force that defines the structure of the universe. Even the people "rethinking gravity" in this video are just doing dark matter with extra steps.

What about accretion? Are we to believe that dark matter + microgravity, which is even weaker than electromagnetism, must also be driving the formation of nebulae, planets, moons, asteroids, etc.? I mean, it's one thing to propose that there is invisible matter that nobody can hear, touch, smell, or taste but quite another to claim that there's 5x more of it than visible matter

We already know that 99% of all visible matter is plasma and that plasma has high field permittivity and, subsequently, high field coherence when in flux. It's not that hard to imagine that the "extra" force is due to field coherence rather than some imaginary matter. Likewise, we could actually explain gravity as the result of field incoherence (imagine clumping a bunch of magnets into a ball without aligning their poles: other magnets are attracted to the ball of magnets regardless of which pole you present)

But by all means, let's keep doubling down on dark matter and burning billions of dollars on more imaginary particle detectors. Maybe with a large enough detector, we will be able to detect the emperor's seemingly invisible clothes.

I'm a PhD candidate working on DM and I think this video was great. I see so much discussion online where people assume scientists are just being narcissistic when we assume DM exists and that it must be like the new version of luminiferous ether theory, because they're not in tune with just how much *independent* evidence we have that is cleanly explained by particle DM.

My only gripe with the entire video would be that I wish you had mentioned specifically that the idea of a particle "we can't see" or being "dark" isn't absurd in the slightest--I think part of why laypeople have gripes with the idea is that they think it's absurd that we could just posit something "invisible" is there. As far as the annual variation in the goes, I suspect it has a very prosaic cause and explanation. Consider a different but parallel sort of issue. The background rate of gamma radiation (and subatomic particles from cosmic rays) varies roughly daily by about 2 microrem per hour. In truth it varies with the sidereal day. It is caused by the rising and falling of the x-ray sources in the Milky Way visible to the Earths surface where the detector resides.

There are a huge number of parameters that vary on an annual cycle. You mentioned a few. There are countless more. I suspect that the chances are high that the Australian experiment will show results 180 degrees out of phase with the Italian results - or - no phase variance at all. Even if they are in phase it does not necessary support CDM. That would only mean that the origin of the annual variation isn’t seasonal in source. Instead then it suggests that it may well be orbital in source.

Dark matter and Dark Energy are illusions. Largely these ideas were driven in the 1970s by the problem that the rotational velocities of galaxies did not match Keplerian based expectations. This is from both the flat radial velocities curves at large sizes relative to the galactic diameter (which you described), and the far more complex problem of the mismatch between Keplerian expectations and observed reality at the smaller scale of the radial velocity curves for distances less that the observed radius of visible stars in galaxies.

At the small radial distances the curves for Andromeda and the Milky Way show a fast core with a roughly linear increase in velocity with distance to the size of the galactic core. Beyond that lies a messy zone we’re radial velocity reverses. Outside that radial velocities rapidly increase then change to roughly a linear velocity increase with distance out to the visible radial size of the galaxy. From that point outward the radial velocity remains constant.

The curves look like a fast rotating solid central section surrounded by a messy reverse velocity zone, that then transitions to an outer zone that rotates like a flat solid plate - except that the inner portion is moving too fast - like Keplerian expectations added to the disk like behavior.

This is not at all what was expected. And trying to force Keplerian expectations on the measured radial velocity curves largely generated the need for dark matter AND dark energy. Nebulae and other observations added to this. This ad hoc approach absolutely is not science. Yet it happened.

What is really at work? That remains unknown. It almost certainly is not dark matter or dark energy or some unknown fifth force.

MOND provides a much simpler - a vastly simpler - explanation. It does not however have an underlying theoretical foundation. But then neither does Cold Dark Matter (CDM) and Dark Energy.

More recent ideas perhaps explain everything.

Consider that gravity isn’t a force - that in point of fact, gravity doesn’t exist at all.

Consider that what we call gravity is an artifact of the distortion of space-time by mass. And that mass isn’t what we imagine either. But for the moment, consider that mass distorts the shape of space-time. Now apply Newtonian motion (at low speeds), and Einsteinian motion at high speeds. The motions remain linear as seen in the distorted space-time. Undistort that to Euclidean space and the motions are complex curves.

Similatly, in distorted space-time the velocities remain constant with motion - barring interactions. Undistort and the motions are anything but linear. Conservation of angular momentum and various moments of inertia; both for object rotations, and for object rotation ‘around’ a center of mass add to this complexity. So too nay electromagnetic conservations and interactions.

These still don’t match observations. Well, not until we add in the expansion of the Universe. Imagine that in Euclidean view as a stretching in all directions. It is more complex than that however as it is a linear change in dimensional size in space-time with time. This is not insignificant at the scale of galaxies and beyond. It is insignificant, I.e. non-observable, at the scale of solar systems.

Now put these all together. Everything fits.

Well, except for that high radial velocity zone in the core of Andromeda and the Milky Way, and likely by extension to all galaxies. What causes that? Why is it distinctly different from the rest of the galaxy? Who knows? That is the realm for new theories and new science.

For now our problem is in getting the old wrong ideas like CDM and Dark Energy to die. If the history of science tells us anything, it is that the time frame for that is the lifetime of the researchers believing these wrong ideas. Only when most of them have grown old and die will the more correct (though often still wrong ideas) prevail. This is the inertia of resistance to discovery.

And given the rate of change of catastrophic climate change, we may well not make it to a truer understanding before the collapse of civilization occurs and perhaps even the end of man as Earth shifts rapidly to an equable climate regime where agriculture as we have known it is impossible. That is unfortunate, as we are I believe on the cusp of a fundamental shift in science. A new age of understanding the nature of reality.

We have experiments that measure the aetherwind.

Dark matter is a fudge factor that got out of hand. Your basic assumptions are obviously incorrect.
The correct assumption is to begin with the Yukawa potential, integrate to get the force and you have an equation that describes star motion in a galaxy. No dark matter needed.
The Yukawa force is 1/R. Setting centripetal equal to a 1/R the Rs cancel and velocity is constant, almost.
The key assumption was made by trying to explain why all star velocities were the same. This could easily be explained if the force between the star and black hole is 1/R.

Derrick - great video, but your history is a little off.  My Father, HW Babcock, was the first to discover effect of dark matter in galaxies in his 1937 thesis, showing the anomalous rotational profile in M33 (Andromeda), and noting the possibility of a "non-luminous" matter source.   This is documented in the Lick Observatory papers from that era and is available online.  (And this was motivated by Fritz Zwicky's similar observations in start clusters.)  Rubin and Ford were well aware of this, and used it to build on in their work in the 1970s, finding it be a general phenomenon.  The omission has found its way into popular expositions on dark matter, and needs to be corrected.  It's strange, because Rubin even references the earlier work in one of her papers.

There are many reasons that the physics community has by and large ignored and not taken the DAMA group's claims of DM detection seriously over the last 2 decades. One, they refused to release their data and methodologies. Two, they never appropriately accounted for their background levels. Three, the absolutely refuse to reconfigure their instrument with a null fiducial volume to see if the signal goes away (like replacing the scintillator crystals with inert glass). Four, they reset their noise floor every year and subtracting out an average noise on an annual basis, despite the noise floor never being constant. And finally now within the last year, fifth, the ANAIS experiment (Annual modulation with NaI Scintillators) which directly replicates DAMA/LIBRA's setup has found absolutely NOTHING over the past 4 years and rules out DAMA's claims at the 99% level. It's already over for DAMA. It's been over for years. This latest replication experiment here will also fail to replicate their claimed annual (and DIURNAL!!) signal detection, and when they do, DAMA will go on just as they always have for the past 20+ years ignoring it and claiming their being "misrepresented". Their group is a pathological pseudoscience group in the same way that cold fusion groups are.

Wow I actually did a seminar on this last semester and especially held a presentation on DAMA/LIBRA. What might additionally be interesting to know is, that there are already two experiments currently running, which try to independently find the same signal as DAMA/LIBRA, named Cosine100 and ANAIS. Both have around three years of measuring time and are starting to become able to judge if the DAMA/LIBRA signal can be reproduced. So far the results of ANAIS seem to indicate no signal can be found, while Cosine is not yet able to make a clear statement, since the bestvalues for certain interesting parameters lie inbetween the zero hypothesis (there is no signal) and the DAMA/LIBRA finding. So right now the trend is leans towards the signal not being due to dark matter, but only time and more experiments will tell, if this ts the case.

Consider:
Galaxies at center mass have a black hole singularity.
To create this singularity takes a threshold of mass and speed/rotation.
This singularity also has incredible attractive force spread evenly over it's rotational mass.
As you approach the singularity your mass becomes more compounded, leading to becoming part of the singularity.
In this way you add to and extend it's attractive mass.
So the rate of rotation is dependant entirely on the singularity, everything else just carries it's energy through the laws of conservation of energy.
The entirety of the system add in to the center of mass, and rotational energy is therefore on average spread evenly over the entirety of the system, given the singularities mass is the driving force across the entire system.
There's no need for dark matter to exist for these things to be true. In effect each orbital body is only transferring the energy from the core out into the edge.
So as the objects nearest the center rotate a direction, they also pull on things a bit further out towards that same direction, and so on and so on, resulting in the spiral shape and conserved speed, since each consecutive layer's speed is based on the speed of the layer before it, which at it's source is the constant speed of rotation set by the singularity

The guy at 14:17 has some info that really should have been frontloaded into the video. It's important to know that the "dark" in "dark matter" is referring to "unknown". This doesn't at all mean that we're looking for one mysterious particle, but rather for whatever is shifting the calculations by such an enormous degree. It's not only possible, but incredibly likely that dark matter is made up of many different undetectable (as of yet) particles that we may discover little by little or only theorize about as we go into the future. The point about changing our model of physics is also a valid theory, but would involve upending most of what we know and finding a brand new set of equations that work with interstellar mass. This means we would have to create and test these new theoretical equations, but then we're getting dangerously close to 'fitting the test to the answer' and throwing in extra numbers, constants, or processes until it's close enough to the answer we need it to be. This of course doesn't solve anything at all, but would now be something that scientists would need to prove or disprove.

Newton didn't know about spiral galaxies. But he was investigating experimentally to determine the effects of the density of a medium on a projectile path through the dense medium. He discovered that an object tends to a hyperbolic trajectory in a dense medium, like a bullet in water and a ball in the air. But in order for a projectile to follow a spiral ('vorticial') path, ... like say matter in a spiral galaxy... He discarded the mathematical solution he had found with this:
"Then the density of the medium would come out as (maths) . But nature does not admit of a negative density, that is, a density which accelerates the motion of bodies; and therefore it cannot naturally come to pass that a body by ascending from P should describe the quadrant PF of a circle. To produce such an effect, a body ought to be accelerated by an impelling medium, and not impeded by a resisting one."

Great Video! I really appreciate the way you (Derek) stay neutral about the 'are there invisible particles or not' question.
Me, i'm not. I think it is ridiculous to assume there must be invisible particles that don't interact in any way (except by gravity), and cannot be directly detected (except by gravity). All we really have is the observation that something causes more gravity to be present in galaxies & clusters than could be caused by the visible matter we can see & detect.
How's this theory: There is no Dark Matter. At least, not in this universe. The excess gravity we observe must be 'leaking' into our universe from regular matter in other universes. Many, many other universes. This idea is (imho) a lot less crazy than the 'invisible particle' idea. And it would certainly explain quite a lot about galaxy / cluster formation, the CMB blobs, the Bullet-Cluster, etc. Think about it... The presence of mass in one universe would, through gravitational leakage, subtly influence the distribution of matter in 'neighbouring' universes. And vice-versa.

Which is more likely:
A) There's a type of matter that only interacts gravitationally, makes up 85% of all matter in the universe, and we have thus far been completely unable to verify it's existence whatsoever, or
B) We have only been able to detect about 15% of all the normal matter in the universe, with the overwhelming majority of the interstellar medium having gone undetected due to being at cosmic background temperature and not reflecting any radiation in our direction.
I am overwhelmingly convinced that cosmologists are drastically overestimating their ability to detect material in space, and option 'B' is far less dependent on far flung merely theoretical explanations, so I'm with option 'B'. At this point the field of cosmology appears to be suffering from major sunk cost fallacy from the millions spent with no results.

I don't think dark matter exists. My hypothesis is that space is actually finite. All energy and mass occupying space is actually not meant to be there. So, space was forcefully expanded in the big bang to an extent that everything is tightly wound in the universe.

For example... Imagine that water was filled to capacity in a plastic/elastic container (finite space). Now, without opening the container introduce air into that container (the big bang). Because the container is elastic and mildly expandable the introduced air expands the container a bit but it's very, very tight. Because of the tight pressure, the air is basically broken into bubbles/air pockets (galaxies/stars/matter/energy - celestial bodies) because of how tight the water container is. In this case all the air pockets would still expand outward buuuut closer air pockets would be attracted to each other (gravity). Now, if the container was open, those air pockets (stars in a galaxy) would swirl around each other normally with the outward air pockets moving slower, but since the container is closed the air pockets behave differently because of the tight space.

I know this may somewhat contradict the general relativity theory but that was a theory anyway too. I wonder if there would be an experiment you could do to test something around this theory.

Fabrics can be stretched, pressured, and/or heated to the point of causing a deformation and losing its elastic nature. All of these conditions were extreme during inflation, so it is plausible that the “fabric” of spacetime analog could extend having its elastic property have hit a yield point?

Perhaps nothing has been detected because there is nothing to detect. GR wouldn’t require modification because DM would just be an extension of how spacetime behaves at extreme conditions. If we liken space to something like a thick layer of iron powder spread out on a table, then we place a magnet in the middle of the powder. Newton's equations for gravity worked exceedingly well on scales we deal with everyday, but broke down at the scale of the solar system.  Obsessed with preserving the eloquence of the theory, scientists then predicted an unobserved substance (dust, an apt name as it turned out) to account for the discrepancy.  Instead, an updated understanding of gravity was needed, and Einstein obliged.  Einstein's theory of gravity worked exceedingly well up to the scale of the solar system and beyond, but broke down at the scale of an entire galaxy.  Even with that fact, we're so obsessed with the eloquence of his theory, we're unwilling to even consider that history might simply be repeating itself, that an update is again needed, that we didn't have the whole picture a hundred years ago.  Again, an unobserved culprit has been conjured.  Dark matter again, is an apt name for an imaginary substance that physicists use to blind themselves from the more likely possibility; that Einstein didn't have all the pieces, standing here on this tiny speck looking outward to the stars, imagining elevators and trains, not even aware of the existence of other galaxies, nor the scale of the cosmos.

There is an elephant in the room explanation for the abnormally high rotation rates of stars in spiral galaxies (the reason for the theory of dark matter). Einstein explained it in the 1939 journal "Annals of mathematics". Wherever you have an astronomical quantity of mass "dilation" (sometimes called gamma or y) will occur. Mass that is dilated is smeared through spacetime relative to an outside observer. If you look at a common relativity graph, with velocity on the horizontal line and dilation on the vertical, the phenomenon is clear, even mass that exists at 75% light speed is partially dilated.
There is no place in the universe where mass is more concentrated than at the center of a galaxy. 99.8% of the mass in our solar system is in the sun. 99.9% of the mass in an atom is in the nucleus. If these norms are true for galaxies than we can infer that there is 100's of trillions of solar masses at the center of common spiral galaxies. There is no way to know through observation, there is far too much interference, dilation and gravitational lensing. High mass means high momentum. If we attribute a radius to these numbers than we can calculate that relativistic velocities exist in these regions.
The mass at the center of our own galaxy is dilated, in some sublime way that mass is all around us because as the graph shows we are still connected to it. The recent discovery that low mass galaxies (like NGC 1052-DF2) have normal star rotation rates is confirmation that dilation is the governing phenomenon at galactic centers. This is what relativity would predict because there is an insufficient quantity of mass to achieve relativistic velocities.
The fact that mass will dilate when it approaches the speed of light is something we all learned in high school at it perfectly explains the greatest mystery in science. There is no "mystery" mass, there is just mass at differing degrees of dilation.

Edit: Also galactic rotation is a bad indicator for dark matter as the orbital velocities are based on keplerian motion, which assumes that the mass is concentrated in the center while the orbiting bodies' mass is negligible. This is plainly not the case for galaxies, and as such the keplerian results are to be taken with a grain of salt.
Galactic rotation shows a linear relation for the inner parts, suggesting that the denser regions are in some way gravitationally linked such that they rotate as a solid body would. After the linear part the rotational velocity mostly goes constant out towards the truncation, which may be dark matter, may also just be non-keplerian orbital motion. All in all dark matter seems sus.

Two "dark matter" theories I miss a discussion on:
1. There is no universal coordinate system. Each system is connected to neighbour systems like the phase boundaries in a superfluid. We see the effect of swirls existing around subsystems that has a near uniform rotation and speed relative to our system, and with their own emergent general relativity - due to their locally emerged uniform coordinate systems, held together (made rigid) by existance of the local interactions there.
2. There are four orthogonal equally probable "time" directions for any 4D structure that has a quantized translational invariance. Since we are built from such particles, we have one of them. But there are three others that cannot interact with us except through gravity if general relativity is perfectly uniform.

If we measure exactly 25% "real matter", it follows then that there can be only one universal general relativity. But we don't. So there must be a dispersion of subsystems with different GR rotation and speed relative to us, and/or each system is not perfectly rigid so the four "time" directions in each system are not perfectly orthogonal everywhere and on all scales that matter for a particle.

Since we see both dark matter and dark energy as almost independent phenomena, the correct word is not or but and on the and/or above. They are about two almost independent dispersion phenomena. One due to local order, the other due to phase boundaries, in any 4D system of 1D-periodic structures, like us.

One of the fascinating things about modern science is the way that it has flipped the role of observation in the process. It used to be that the point of science was to make dispassionate observations, from which we could draw very limited conclusions, and eventually more general theories. But now we take our existing theories as the starting point, and the role of the scientist is to find observations that confirm the theories. If the observations stubbornly refuse to confirm the theories, then, instead of taking this as evidence of weaknesses in the theories, we instead take it as evidence of the existence of random stuff that we can't detect.

If we were talking minor discrepancies, then reasoning along these lines might be justifiable, kind of how they discovered Pluto by observing discrepancies in Neptune's orbit. (But I may have the planets wrong here). But if you need to say that 85% of the matter in the universe is undetectable in order to make your theories work, I think it is far more likely that your theory is just plain wrong. And it would be much more fruitful to try to devise a theory that conforms to observations.

Though the existence of dark matter is indisputable, one has to point out it accelerated the ruin of particle physics. Our obsession with grants and "publish or perish" has let to people non-stop publishing speculative nonsense papers - and what's easier to latch onto than dark matter? All that's important anymore is how many stupid papers you write swearing that your particular iteration of SUSY or Axions or... is exactly what describes that dark matter. Then funding gets coughed up and sometimes another nonsense experiment is built.
BTW I'd cool it with Dama/Libra - their methodology (they don't release everything they do to the public, so that's immediately suspicious) is very flawed and their background subtraction method can account for most of the "signal" they see. Furthermore there already are experiments designed to double check their results and those returned empty handed (e.g. Anais in Spain)

Dark Matter is mass from the anti-matter universe/alternate universes.
Where the DM is high, the matter of the other universes is in the same/similar distribution as ours.
Where DM is low, the other universes turned out differently.

I think there's a much better answer to the question "do you think that dark matter interacts with ordinary matter" than the one given here. It's that we share one universe, and that universe had a beginning. At some point, the dark matter had to be created, and unless two separate big bangs happened simultaneously, dark matter and ordinary matter must share a common origin near the big bang. Whatever earlier particle gave rise to dark matter and ordinary matter must interact with both, and therefore ordinary matter should be able to interact with dark matter using that earlier particle as a mediator.

The WIMP model wasn't made to motivate how we might be able to detect dark matter, it was motivated by trying to explain how dark matter was created in the early universe. In fact, most theoretical dark matter models primarily struggle with making sure that the model explains why dark matter is present in the universe. Then if the model also has a detectable signal, great. But it certainly isn't used as a requirement.
